title: ‘Meh’
pros: There are excellent opportunities to be exposed to a wide range of clients and become a sector specialist as more junior levels than most firms. The senior management is excellent and genuinely care about your career progression. Ultimately you're primed to be an excellent employee somewhere else.
cons: As with all big four firms, the pay is lower than the rest of the industry but you're expected to be ok with this because of the 'great opportunities' you're presented with. Because great opportunities pay the bills...

title: ‘Worst company I worked in my 23 years of professional life.’
pros: Good for graduates who can work 16 -18 hours a day like a machine.
cons: Horrible work culture, they treat employees like money making machine. Complete disregard of human feelings. Nothing is important for them than their margin and big fat bonus for the partners and directors.

title: ‘A motivational place that taught me so much and gave me long time friendships.’
pros: Amazing culture, good diversity with people who are passionate about their jobs and succeeding for the company.  Great incentives for learning and development plus a team environment that makes you want to come to work everyday.  Great policies, great strategies and being ejncouraged to have a day to work for a charity is truly amazing.
cons: Trying to get new processes across to other teams.  Using global policies for local work sometimes was frustrating.

title: ‘Challenging, demanding and busy which pushes for individual growth’
pros: The opportunity for women to develop, the variety of clubs and social events you are able to join after work hours, opportunity to get involved in a variety of projects, the set up of mentors and buddying system for new staff, clear vision and end of year performance structure
cons: No proper training was given for the role (peer to peer), no work life balance (working after hours and starting early, missing lunch breaks), tough work enviornment (no 'one team') vision, pay was not great and the stakeholders have strong and different personalities, busy busy busy!

title: ‘Buyer beware, Although good at times Big 4 is not all its cracked up to be’
pros: Excellent exposure to largest clients in Australia, good assistance with attaining CA qualifications, large work team and plenty of social functions meaning that it is easy to make friends. Opportunities to learn from industry leading partners.
cons: Terrible work life balance (late nights and weekends are rarely awarded genuine thanks), training not executed properly, a 'throwing under the bus' culture from management towards juniors just so they don't look bad, flawed workflow system where managers opinions of staff will affect who they give work to.

title: ‘EY sell you a grand story about their focus on culture, career progression and a younger workforce. They have a younger workforce due to high turn over as they expect their staff to work long hours for low wages compared to industry competitors. They have’
pros: Young dynamic workforce, offers perks such as flexible working and staff recognition
cons: Heavy workload vs low pay. Their expectations from you as an employee outweigh their staff recognition and the low pay compared to industry standards. Poor leadership with poor assistance in career progression. Their system of \"counsellor vs counsellee\" sets the expectation that the employee must initiate their monthly 121s and any 'performance concerns' should be raised by the employee.

title: ‘A mix of knowledge gained and balance lost. ’
pros: Knowledge base together with the opportunity to learn your profession is a strong aspect to consider at EY. As the management team and partners have a strong technical background.
cons: Work life balance needs to be improved

title: ‘It's a great experience to work at such a large company and I made a lot of friends during my time here which I am thankful for.’
pros: Working with smart and motivated people, the social side of things and the friendships made are the good things about working at EY as an EA. A lot of the partners are strong leaders and very busy and rely on their EA's heavily.
cons: Poor leadership from the EA team leaders. A disrespect for EA's within teams who can belittle what we do by giving meaningless tasks. Barely any career progression or development in the EA space and very small salary increases yearly, if any at all while being exposed to everyone else's increase in salaries yearly can be confronting. Long working hours and heavy workload.

title: ‘Tough at times but rewarding.’
pros: EY genuinely cares about its people and wants to do the right thing by them. They provide flexibility and opportunities to develop.
cons: Politics, but that goes for all workplaces.

title: ‘High intensity learning environment that will lead to better opportunities in other organisations with a higher focus on worklife balance.’
pros:
Excellent L&D opportunities based on experiences, coaching and a superior L&D Dept.

There are clear expectations of each role and a clear career path mapped out leading to good career progression opportunities.
cons:
Working in a Partnership is difficult, too many people wanting to drive and far too many decisions being made based on relationships or politics rather than sound business judgement.  There is a very clear lack of leadership.

Really poor work-life balance, expectations are high and it is almost impossible to meet expectations within normal work hours, there is a prevalent culture where working outside of hours is expected but in no way acknowledged.

title: ‘Absolutely amazing, highly recommended!’
pros: Unbelievable learning opportunities from working cross division to overseas secondments. Absolutely amazing corporate culture focused on high achieving teams and developing future leaders.
cons: Stress during the busy season - however you always get support.

title: ‘Horrible. I would never go back. ’
pros: There are some excellent people who work for EY, they have some excellent clients and having it on your CV will put you in good stead for future opportunities. Also, some teams are probably quite good, but not the case for mine unfortunately.
cons: The pay is abominable, unbelievably low! The actual business is managed so poorly, there is so much potential but unfortunately the culture is toxic and encourages competition. The turnover rate reflects this.

title: ‘An amazing place to work if you don't mind burning out in a few years.’
pros: High intensity working environment with incredibly talented colleagues. Many learning opportunities, work experiences and a global outlook.
cons: Some parts of the business are a bit like Game of Thrones; you win (become a partner) or you die. Other parts are more relaxed. You will experience high levels of stress and are expected to work long hours. It can be difficult to find the fabled work life balance. This is made harder by working in a global role. Expect to work all day then spend every night on the phone with your international colleagues.

title: ‘Great place to work to gain experience and move on’
pros: Professionalism and opportunities for development
cons: Work life balance. For someone who has little kids difficult to succeed as business requires to be flexible and often stay late.

title: ‘A smart group of people limited by a lack of innovative spirit and a failure to live the values they claim to be the EY-way.’
pros: Decent employee benefits.  Impressive personal growth opportunity.  Human Resources (as with a lot or large businesses) are only an extension of Management without demonstrating any really advocacy for the employees beyond rhetoric.
cons: EY spends a lot of time promoting their Diversity and Inclusiveness program.  However, my experience saw a lot of 1980's behavior toward women and progression in the workplace (I am male).

title: ‘A very challenging 12 months. ’
pros: EY is a place that wants to do the right things and so there is a lot of goodwill in the organisation.
cons: I worked in a specialty area of the firm that was an emerging focus for the firm. Consequently there were significant resourcing and leadership issues that impacted on the ability of the team to grow and deliver strong engagements. Aside from delivering engagements in my speciality area I was required to deliver mainstream engagements for an area in which I had no formal training or expertise.

title: ‘Stuck in the past’
pros: Great flexibility and ability to work remotely. Technology is excellent.
cons: Promotion and career opportunities based on tenure not performance. A lot of long term employees who are resistant to change and maintain the status quo no matter how inefficient. The image that EY projects a best practice, forward thinking business is not reflected internally.

title: ‘Bad experience!’
pros: Good exposure to a variety of clients.
cons: It's all about which partner you have impressed. If you only work for partners that do not have influence ( no matter how hard you work) , you won't be rising up the ranks.
location: City of Perth, Perth, Western Australia, Australia

title: ‘Culturally very sheltered and uninspiring place to work’
pros: Flexible working arrangements
cons: Not a great deal of support and hard to communicate with internal stakeholders.

title: ‘Great career opportunities but work/life balance is hard to manage’
pros: Career opportunities
cons: Poor work life balance, TAS requires exceptional commitment.

title: ‘The company is focussed on outsourcing Austarlian jobs for themselved and their customers’
pros: It is an international company
cons: They outsource a large part of their work off shore

title: ‘No matter whenever you join, however long you stay, exceptional EY experience stays with you for a Lifetime!!’
pros: Opportunities, Growth, People
cons: Working on tight Deadlines, Multitasking, meeting very high expectations!

title: ‘Building a better working world’
pros: Culture, people, career opportunities
cons: Remuneration, work life balance, benefits/perks

title: ‘I am liking it. The only problem is the salary, it is above the average.’
pros: Carrer and benefits. You can learn a lot and they invest in you.
cons: You will have different bosses, it is difficult to please all.
location: Sydney, Nova Gales do Sul, Austrália

title: ‘Good place to start your career but not somewhere I would stay for long.’
pros: Clear progression levels and opportunity to experience vastly different clientele.
cons: Hard to gain recognition, rating system very much flawed, poor work life balance

title: ‘Increase the benefit provided to employee.’
pros: EY has enough projects. Good work life balance.flexibility.
cons: Poor management. More politics.

title: ‘Experience that will last a lifetime’
pros: Diversity and inclusiveness. Range of work. Access to top management.
cons: Work life balance is difficult to achieve but the range of work is both challenging and rewarding.

title: ‘Great place to work’
pros: Diversity and flexible working arrangements. Always being challenged mentally, in a good way.
cons: Working long hours and stress of meeting deadlines

title: ‘Employer of choice’
pros: Highly mature business processes. Great brand name.
cons: All good however sometimes one feels a bit mechanical.

title: ‘Exceptional place to work’

title: ‘Disappointed ’

cons: Toxic culture at Partner level in Consulting

title: ‘A great foundation towards your chosen career’
pros: Great Career opportunities, training and development, unlimited learning opportunities
cons: Work-life balance is difficult to manage

title: ‘Great place to establish career’

title: ‘Great place to work for’

Operationally, there are many disjointed systems and ambiguous processes which make it difficult to get anything done.

title: ‘Don’t do it, especially don’t work in CBS.’
pros: Diversity.  There’s a lot of inspiring people.  The brand looks good on your resume.
cons: The work load is excessive.  EY allows partners to treat their staff badly.  The pay is terrible.  Decisions by management are not well thought out and EY employs some incompetent people usually in positions of power.

title: ‘EY is a fantastic firm to work for, professional, progressive and flexible’
pros: EY has a great culture, very inclusive, very open to flexible arrangements and spends time and focus on having a great work environment.
cons: The pay wasn't as high as I would expect from a firm such as this.

title: ‘Good for entry level jobs - c/sc but not for experienced professionals’
pros: Good entry level jobs and great learning curve
cons: Very poor pay. High costing cutting measures in place as they have been underperforming for 2-3 years in a row.

title: ‘Diverse work experience, but long hours for little pay’
pros:
- Great peer group who are very social
- diverse exposure to clients and industries
cons:
- Working hours are too long relative to pay
- Often make up credentials or sell underqualified resources to clients
- focus is always on chargeable hours which comes at the cost of employee wellbeing and quality

title: ‘Career changing experience.’
pros: Working day to day with some of the smartest and brightest people in the assurance and advisory consulting business.
cons: Staying on top of individual goals while managing quality work at clients.  While this is common in the Big 4, and EY is very supportive, one must be up for a serious challenge professionally.

title: ‘Great place to start up the career’
pros: Fast learning curve, multiple culture, helpful people
cons: Pressure of learning, time management. Not easy to make friends apart from regular team members

title: ‘Great team and support, pathetic work life balance and pay’
pros: Good to start the career, proper training, with positive and supportive team overall
cons: Management ‘has favourites’ in terms of work allocation and and promotions, pay is significantly lower than the market

title: ‘Good opportunity to start in life!’
pros: You get to work with amazing and diverse teams of passionate people. The employees are young so that creates a nice atmosphere. You can learn a lot of managerial skills.
cons: You work long hours and don’t really have a work life balance. During busy season, you are expected to work at night and over the week end
location: Cité de Sydney, Nouvelle-Galles du Sud, Australie

title: ‘Great Culture, not so great career progression or salary.’
pros: Great culture and social events. Open plan working and flexibility to work remotely/flexibly.
cons: No career progression for EA's and little to no pay rise each year, not based on performance. Based on the budget that the firm gives for EA pay rises. Rigid middle management and partners have no say over the career progression for their EA's.

title: ‘A great step up in my career’
pros: The people you work with
cons: Resisting the big salaries thrown at you after 2 years

title: ‘Great place to work’
pros:
Career development,

cons:

title: ‘No one discuss career path. Too much focus on attire, little on the content(knoweldge). Peers are interested in judging your salary. In today's world, no strategy of what clients to target/ how to target, out of sync with Product companies. Whatever work ’
pros: Salary is at par with market.
cons: Red tapism. and micro management. Simply my worst experience perhaps a nightmare.

Diversity and the opportunities to work on a variety of jobs in Australia and worldwide.
cons: Redundancies were scary... It's often about who you know not how well you work.

title: ‘External view doesn't match the internal process’

title: ‘EY Sydney's Technology Risk (FSO Advisory - Financial Services Advisory) is decent in terms of job demand. The upper management, questionable progression tracks, and employee turnover rates are some of the worst, however. Don't pressure yourself to join a’
job_title: Senior Consultant, Technology Risk, Financial Services, FSO Advisory
pros: This is for EY Sydney's Technology Risk Practice - Financial Services Advisory - FSO Advisory. What you get in terms of career path demand is very high. Some good teammates here and there. You must be extremely lucky to get a good experience, honestly.
cons: Every day is a challenge since most of the work is repetitive and boring. What the managers and up sell in some of their engagements depend on how you see them. They obvious prioritize money over career opportunities and employee satisfaction since its a business. I have bad experience in their upper management structure and progression. Most of the time, they don't do things with reason. This team has a particular reputation for having a high churn rate (turnover rate/lots of people jumping ship right away), which is A BIG RED FLAG FOR AN ORGANIZATION SUCH AS THIS.

title: ‘Constant reorganization hard for stability for teams’
pros: Working coulture
cons: Being global IT, difficult to get / know correct teams to get things done efficiently.

title: ‘Overall good work life balance’
pros: Nice to work for the company that has offices all over the world
cons: Sometimes you feel like a number not a person working for such a big company

title: ‘Met great people and learnt a lot’
pros: Great people; switched on and enthusiastic
cons: Peaks and troughs in work time

title: ‘I met some great people and learned lots about the corporate environment- and I'm now completely changing career because this has been such an awful experience in terms of support, management and mental health (I developed severe depression over the two y’

Management and acceptance of work life balance were terrible as was support during difficult periods. Once management realised there was a mass exodus occurring the started to take more care and concern into the lower ranks' wellbeing- however for me it was too little much too late.

pros: People and culture, opportunities to learn and grow
cons: Time management and high demand

title: ‘Good learning environment with lots of helpers with tonnes of knowledge base’
pros:
Good partners
Lovely coaches
Lots of stuff for referral and guidance
cons: If in RCIP Department - away from home maybe be hard for those with young family.

title: ‘Worthful time spent and would look forward for opportunities in future.. ’
pros: Excellent Work culture
cons: Sometimes client but EY DNA as a company - Excellent

title: ‘Rewarding and Supportive’
pros: Work/ Life  Balance. Extremely flexible and understanding environment.
cons: Tasks can vary from simple to extremely complex. However, there is plenty of support to help build skills and overcome challenges.

title: ‘Awful, do not work here. ’
pros: Nice offices. Some good clients.
cons: Colleagues, managers, partners, some clients aren’t good.

title: ‘Great experience with a well known brand’
pros: Challenging and exciting with equality
cons: Long hours

title: ‘Good place’
pros: Fair
cons: Work hard

title: ‘Generally they don't treat their staff very well.’
pros: Good brand to work for and experience gained in a global organisation
cons: Some challenging personalities at leadership level. IT systems were overly complex time consuming and frustrating.

title: ‘It was a great experiences’
pros: We know lot of new things
cons: All of the deadline and how to manage it

title: ‘Looks great from the outside and on your CV, but is just used as experience for most due to perpetuation of high turnover culture. ’
pros: Nice view, flexibility depending on your engagement, hours are great for most juniors.
cons: Easy to be bored and lack purpose even with lots of work, lip service to things like culture which is actually very cold, clinical work space, lots of people who want to leave (which makes things very depressing).

title: ‘It was absolutely horrible.’
pros: Meeting a variety of people from diverse backgrounds.
cons: Micromanagement, little opportunity for progression unless you are a director of partner, constantly being told I need to change my personality, constant gossiping that has no relevance to the work at hand, not enough money for the hours put in.

title: ‘Good company to get experience in big project but worst working culture and management is non existant’
pros: Get to work on bigger projects
cons: Dealing with cheaper resources

title: ‘Good opportunity to jump-start your career, but don't stay for too long if you want to continue doing delivery work and improving your technical skills.’
pros:
- Good soft skill development
- Good work/life balance
cons:
- Bad managers
- Toxic culture
- Unfulfilling work

title: ‘Great people but low pay’
pros: I’m in CBS the internal team, so I have great work life balance and excellent support for professional development
cons: Growth opportunities are less and so is the pay

title: ‘Wouldn't recommend anyone to join ’
pros: Couldn't think of any
cons: Have to work overtime everyday without any compensation. No assistance from managers whatsoever.

title: ‘Great organisation to work for if you have support and backing of a partner and team. ’
pros: Exposed to a wide variety of people, businesses, challenges and technology.
cons: Impossible to progress as a technical resource.

title: ‘Enjoyable and challenging ’
pros: The staff morale and working environment is good.
cons: Clients are always a challenge in an audit space.

title: ‘Learn, learn, learn’
pros: Working with intelligent people, the purpose of building a better working world
cons: Dealing with local leadership, legacy tools and its limitations

title: ‘Career promotion at a price of lower salaries and long hours at work’
pros: Nice teams, management, diversity
cons: Relatively low salaries and expectations being higher every year

title: ‘Exceptional ’
pros: I love the opportunities, the work and the global diversity. Most of all though, I’m valued for my time and effort.
cons: We definitely work hard

title: ‘Enjoyed my time at EY and would go back if the right opportunity presented itself’
pros: Great people and a great place to work
cons: Difficult for someone in business development to get ahead

title: ‘It is good place to work but needs to manage the politics as the hierarchy and bureaucracy could slowdown the career development ’
pros: Lots of learning opportunities, good client base
cons: Political and difficult to grow

title: ‘Pointless ’
pros: Nice office with view
cons: No direction from anyone

title: ‘Should have resigned 3 years earlier’
pros: Some interesting projects
cons: The toxic leadership

title: ‘Ageist organisation ’
pros: Not much..the view from my office
cons: They didn't utilise me

title: ‘Horrible’
pros: My peers and the friendships I gained
cons: Directors and partners

title: ‘EY is home’
pros: The people are great and friendly
cons: Huge volume of work.

title: ‘Great people, great culture’
pros: The people
cons: Work life balance
